reviewText:
Sword of Asumi is an embarrassment to itself. Not because it’s gross and exploitative, or because the art is horrendous, or because it seems to have been written by someone whose sole exposure to human interaction is anime. All of that is terrible in its own, agonizingly expansive way, but what is worst about Sword of Asumi is how little it tries to even pretend it’s anything but a pile of reeking ♥♥♥♥.

Though its introduction says otherwise, Asumi and her narrative are as much about her life as an assassin as it is authentic in its portrayal of the Edo period (which in this universe is supposedly still in effect, despite absolutely nothing actually reflecting that). Sword of Asumi is instead then largely an excuse to strip down its constantly blushing cast (who unless I’m mistaken are also underage). The actual plot, impressively thin as it is, all takes place within the opening and closing five minutes of the game. The rest of the agonizing hour and a half or so is dedicated to carefully positioning the camera so as to best oggle your character while she inexplicably changes into dozens of outfits for the player’s enjoyment.

I don’t know if Sword of Asumi was designed with softcore titillation as its main “feature”, or if that was just something the developer felt they had an obligation to include, but the lengths they have gone to expose and embarrass every female character in the game made me sick. It apparently wasn’t enough for them to stop at the typical ridiculously large breasts and vacuum sealed clothing that plagues anime and by extension visual novels. Even upon giving Asumi a wardrobe which consists almost entirely of lace lingerie (why is a teenage assassin suddenly wearing a garter belt?) and hav ing her lounge around in it as male classmates spontaneously barge into her room, the writer’s perverted aspirations remained unsatisfied.

So naturally the only thing left to do was create a subplot in which the principal of the school has been sexually assaulting first year students. And then have Asumi show up at his office wearing almost nothing, with the implication being she plans to offer herself up in exchange for information (which is never found, and which doesn’t matter in the end anyway). The scene is cut short before anything happens, but of course not before Asumi is stripped nearly naked and harassed by the principal (who is such a pointless character he wasn’t even given a portrait). It’s a disgusting, lazy plot device that goes nowhere and serves no function but to be another bullet point on Sword of Asumi’s list of exploitative tactics. I was legitimately flabbergasted then when the writer were able to make this subplot even worse, by bringing it up later on and painting the principal as a sympathetic victim of blackmail, in the process literally forgiving him of his crimes and going so far as to have Asumi feel sorry for him.

I was prepared to dismiss Sword of Asumi as yet another poorly drawn, terribly written, abhorrently exploitative visual novel, but it went beyond rudimentary objectification to a degree that caused me to detest its very existence. I can’t even assume the writer has any idea what a sloppy piece of trash he has produced, because Sword of Asumi is so poorly constructed that it just feels like a bag of ideas and tropes pulled from the depths of anime hell to be reconstructed into something that could potentially be passed off as original. I can’t in good conscious actually call it original, but it’s definitely the product of a very particular, insular audience and the creators which spawn from it, a group I can only hope one day wakes up to the messes they’ve made.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

From its promising beginning, it becomes yet another school-centric dating sim, and the rebel plot hardly plays into the story at all until near the end. I've got a lot of Visual Novels finished, not enough to consider myself any accomplished expert, but enough to know what I want AND the difference between what I want, and what I expect.

Sadly, Sword of Asumi is NOT polished at all. I got it in a bundle, and being honest, would not have otherwise picked it up - most especially not at that price (mainly because I've seen more polished and complete games set out for far less, more than any mispricing - no comment on that, since a person has the right to price their wares as much as they see fit). I perked up when I saw it was a visual novel, but things didn't really pick up from there.

The story and characters aren't anything special, and the choices to pick to steer the route a certain direction are as clear as day (you can probably get an ending with a person by solely ALWAYS picking the choice that their name appears in - aside from actually attending things they'd be at). The art has its own charm, but the very obvious and blatant fanservice seems to impact my opinion on the art as a whole (kudos to the artist for drawing that many different sets of underwear for one character, though - I do believe each day is a different racy matching set). That's not to say it wasn't good - I can appreciate the work and effort and the final output, even... it's just not to my personal taste, and there are things I think can be improved on.

There were a lot of bugs when I first played it - text where they shouldn't be, wrong labels and names, generally a lot of things that just outright confused me and threw me off - and there are still bugs. For one, Achievements on Macs were completely unresponsive before... supposedly, an update fixed it, but now my record of Achievements looks weirder since I got awarded for finishing certain routes (not all of them trigger their respective achievements) but NOT the Achievement for completing the game (for the first time). Achievements aren't usually necessary to begin with, but if you add them, do see to it that it works.

Still, I will have to give props to the developer - there is serious work on spreading Sword of Asumi to mobile devices and any bugs that get reported get seen to. There is a strong developer presence in the forums, and new builds keep coming up trying to see to what problems people point out.

Kudos to that, I can really respect that.

reviewText:
This visual novel feature a female assassin Asumi from the Black Clan who is approached by a Justicar Kami to enrol in classes at Battle Academy and attempt to discover the identity and eliminate The Raven within the academy who is planning an armed rebellion and overthrow the current Edo rulers through a major terrorist attack. At the academy, Asumi is introduced to her fellow classmate and immediate dormitory room neighbour Kaori, her academy prefects Mineko and Utsuro, members of the presidential squad Hikari, Keiji and Sen along with additional minor supporting characters.

Asumi's study at the academy begins by being simple and innocent, with the option to attend a choice of course subject to study or practice in and make a good or bad impression on any of the four characters Kaori, Mineko, Utsuro or Hikari she can date, fall in love with and eventually obtain a good, neutral or bad ending.

The story will gain momentum and start to become more fast-paced with the death or dismissal of the academy principal, several mysterious student deaths, the departure of Asumi's handler Kami back to the capital, the arrival of several mysterious black garbed figures, a kidnapping on the replacement academy principal and eventually Asumi expressing her love to a main character and a final confrontation with one of the main characters.

reviewText:
It's decent but I would recommend getting it on a sale, along with the accompying graphic novel.

Story:
The basic story line is interesting if barebones. Still, being an assassin is fun, even if there is a lot of socializing and SOL action between the assassin antics. The story itself does not change much no matter who you decide to romance, which diminishes replay value; in fact, the canonical ending has you romance no one. In addition, it's pretty much the set up for the graphic novel with the much more interesting story, which is why I recommended to buy that specifically with this VN.

Characters:
The romancable characters are all surprisingly moe, even the guys (no homo). In particular, Hikari radiates moe from every pore of his body (no homo, totally). In any case, I enjoyed the interactions between Asumi and the romantic interests; seeing how Asumi interacts with them makes the game replayable even if almost all of the overarching plot remains the same no matter what. A shame that none of the romanceable characters appear in the graphic novel story at all.

Art:
The sprite art is pretty good, and the CG art isn't necessarily bad, but there is a jarring inconsistency between the CG art and sprite art. Personally, that bothers me more than consistently bad art.

In conclusion, if you're bored and this is on a sale, this will alleviate your boredom a bit. It's not spectacular, but it's somewhat enjoyable.

reviewText:
I backed this game, and although I had access to the backer build, I decided to wait until release. I quite enjoyed having a female protagonist, and there was a fair bit of art variety in this, too. The music was pretty good, especially the main menu music, which was very haunting. I liked most of the characters in this, too, and even if first impressions of some weren't the best, like Utsuru, they had some surprises for you, and end up being quite likable. The game gives you a lot of choices as well, so if you're looking for a VN that gives you a lot of options, meaningful or otherwise, Sword of Asumi has you covered.

It's not all good, I hate to say. The game is still riddled with typos despite being released - most of them are clustered together in scenes so it looks like segments were missed during editing. However, the dev is actively patching the game to correct this, even as I write, so it may not be the case later. The game is also very short - you can finish it in a couple of hours and the ending doesn't exactly feel satisfying. It feels rushed and ends rather abruptly once you complete your mission. It doesn't feel like there's much in the way of replay value, either, unfortunately, despite several people you can fall in love with. Ultimately who you fall in love with has little influence on the ending. A forever alone good end is possible, too - and has some great art - which is nice, although it isn't explicit and can make a dead end more likely for reasons I'm unsure of.

It sounds like I'm being overly negative, but I did enjoy this game. I'm just disappointed that there isn't more - a few extra hours for more investigation would help add to this, and maybe a little more school related stuff, as well as an expanded upon ending and conclusion outside of a few lines summarising what you'd be able to infer. Also, an editor to go over it and fix up the grammar would help with my enjoyment. These are mistakes that a basic spell check would pick up, amongst others, and a VN should be held to high standards given the amount of reading you do. I look forward to seeing how future games will improve, and I wouldn't mind a return to this universe, or perhaps an expansion.

reviewText:
Not too bad. The game itself can be finished in a short evening.

The visual novel aspect is decently done since there are actual choices with reasonable impact the player can make, like whether to simply kill or disable the few targets the game has. The characters are also interesting.

The main art for the characters is decently done. The cinematic imagery is noticeably worse- probably by a different artist who isn't bad, but isn't using the same style as the game's basic sprites. Going from the in-game sprites to the cinematic images is very jarring because of the change in styles.

The story is understandable and enjoyable, but it is also filled with grammatical errors, punctuation errors, spelling errors, and all sorts of issues that make it seem as though there was no editor for the material.

Ultimately, I would recommend playing through this if you can get it for cheap during a Steam Sale or through an indie bundle. It's not fantastic by any means, but It's an enjoyable good waste of time.
